revision.text: {{WPMILHIST|class=start | |B-Class-1=no |B-Class-2=yes |B-Class-3=yes |B-Class-4=yes |B-Class-5=yes |Fortifications-task-force=yes}} ==Untitled== Surely "In the United States Marine Corps, foxholes are often referred to as fighting holes" should say "In the United States Marine Corps, '''DFPs''' are often referred to as fighting holes". Also, the difference between fighting and hiding is not small or philosophical. [[User:Open4D|Open4D]] ([[User talk:Open4D|talk]]) 03:19, 28 November 2007 (UTC) == Derivation == I removed this text: :The word '''foxhole''' is a [[homophone]] of fo'c'sle, which is a [[syncope]] of the word [[forecastle]], which likely referred to defensive fighting positions on the battlefield forward of castle walls. First, they are not homophones (at least not the way I speak English). Second, in the absence of a citation this seems like an implausible [[folk etymology]]. Surely a foxhole is a hole similar to the one a [[fox]] lives in? [[User:Cyclopaedic|Cyclopaedic]] ([[User talk:Cyclopaedic|talk]]) 10:49, 27 September 2009 (UTC) Not only that, but fo'c'sle or forecastle is a part of a ship, not a land-based structure. [[Special:Contributions/69.29.207.109|69.29.207.109]] ([[User talk:69.29.207.109|talk]]) 01:26, 30 October 2009 (UTC) == Foxhole? == "Defensive fighting position" sounds very much like a technical military term used only by military people. As far as I know, this would be known to most people as a foxhole, so describing that term as "slang" and basically equating it with real army slang like "ranger grave" and "fighting hole" doesn't seem accurate at all. According to [http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/foxhole dictionary.com], the term has been around since WW I and is used in the literature all the time, and certainly not as some kind of colloquialism. Also, compare hits for "DFP" and "foxhole". The former gets you 1,160 hits[http://www.google.se/#sclient=psy&hl=sv&safe=off&source=hp&q=%22defensive+fighting+position%22+-wikipedia&aq=f&aqi=&aql=&oq=&pbx=1&bav=on.2,or.r_gc.r_pw.&fp=1f4ec568a22df14c&biw=1680&bih=959] while the latter scores 406,000[http://www.google.se/#sclient=psy&hl=sv&safe=off&source=hp&q=%22foxhole%22+-wikipedia&aq=f&aqi=&aql=&oq=&pbx=1&bav=on.2,or.r_gc.r_pw.&fp=1f4ec568a22df14c&biw=1680&bih=959]. The foxhole-search includes a lot that isn't military, but adding terms like "soldier", "war" or "battle" still gets you around 100k hist. If you try searching on Google Books, "DFP" scores 80 hits[http://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&tbo=1&q=%22Defensive+fighting+position%22&btnG=Search+Books] while "foxhole +"world war II" alone scores 9,790 hits[http://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&tbo=1&q=%22Defensive+fighting+position%22&btnG=Search+Books#hl=en&ds=bo&pq=%22foxhole%22%20%2Bfighting&xhr=t&q=%22foxhole%22%20%2B%22world%20war%20II%22&cp=12&qe=ImZveGhvbGUiICsid29ybGQgd2FyIElJIg&qesig=kC13zxuNJ2A9qL2pBf4cQw&pkc=AFgZ2tlChP1L5BNqryfIbKdRZ5oCjDW2XSto0Fx7ReAd9QqeSvst93FB_8zhz6cs2jbmrtP7CKI2g2CU5o3dNSzbdSwmuZq6FQ&pf=p&sclient=psy&tbo=1&biw=1680&bih=959&tbm=bks&source=hp&aq=f&aqi=&aql=&oq=%22foxhole%22+%2B%22world+war+II%22&pbx=1&bav=on.2,or.r_gc.r_pw.&fp=d636e0cc151b7d8d] A minor rewrite seems appropriate. [[User:Peter Isotalo|Peter]] [[User talk:Peter Isotalo|Isotalo]] 18:57, 3 July 2011 (UTC) :Agreed. Anyone support or object to such a change?[[User:Morgan Riley|Morgan Riley]] ([[User talk:Morgan Riley|talk]]) 06:09, 15 February 2014 (UTC) ::I think DFP has been chosen because its neutral, whereas "foxhole" is an American term; most other English-speaking nations use "[fire] trench" etc. In any case this article covers defensive positions that are not foxholes or trenches e.g. sangars and shell scrapes.
